title: Set-theoretic limit
text:
In <a href="mathematics">mathematics</a>, the limit of a <a href="sequence">sequence</a> of <a href="Set%20%28mathematics%29">sets</a> formula_1 (<a href="subset">subset</a>s of a common set formula_2) is a set whose elements are determined by the sequence in either of two equivalent ways: (1) by upper and lower bounds on the sequence that converge monotonically to the same set (analogous to <a href="Limit%20of%20a%20sequence">convergence of real-valued sequences</a>) and (2) by convergence of a sequence of <a href="indicator%20function">indicator function</a>s which are themselves <a href="Real%20number">real</a>-valued. As is the case with sequences of other objects, convergence is not necessary or even usual.
More generally, again analogous to real-valued sequences, the less restrictive limit infimum and limit supremum of a set sequence always exist and can be used to determine convergence: the limit exists if the limit infimum and limit supremum are identical. (See below). Such set limits are essential in <a href="Measure%20%28mathematics%29">measure theory</a> and <a href="probability">probability</a>.

This article is restricted to that situation as it is the only one relevant for measure theory and probability. See the examples below. (On the other hand, there are more general <a href="Limit%20superior%20and%20limit%20inferior%23General%20set%20convergence">topological notions of set convergence</a> that do involve accumulation points under different <a href="Metric%20%28mathematics%29">metrics</a> or <a href="Topological%20space">topologies</a>.)

Probability uses.
Set limits, particularly the limit infimum and the limit supremum, are essential for <a href="probability">probability</a> and <a href="Measure%20%28mathematics%29">measure theory</a>. Such limits are used to calculate (or prove) the probabilities and measures of other, more purposeful, sets.
